KA.IUHCI.content: nature intends man beyond nature: nature does not do things superfluously > nature has give man the capacity not to follow inclination or instinct but to produce it out of himself [is this a paradox?] > man’s kindness of will achieved by man’s own work > “nature intended that man should owe it all to himself”
KA.IUHCI.linkedContent: nature intends man beyond nature: nature does not do things superfluously > nature has give man the capacity not to follow inclination or instinct but to produce it out of himself [is this a paradox?] > man’s kindness of will achieved by man’s own work > “nature intended that man should owe it all to himself”

KA.IUHCI.content: transition, by way of continuous enlightenment, from a pathologically enforced co-ordination of society into a moral whole > raw natural faculty of moral discrimination becomes practical principles
KA.IUHCI.linkedContent: transition, by way of continuous enlightenment, from a pathologically enforced co-ordination of society into a moral whole > raw natural faculty of moral discrimination becomes practical principles

KA.EP.content: the 3 principles of republican constitution: freedom, dependence on common legislation, equality of all as citizens
KA.EP.linkedContent: the 3 principles of republican constitution: freedom, dependence on common legislation, equality of all as citizens

KA.EP.content: democracy refers to who can hold the highest power > republic refers to method by which people are governed (republicanism: principle acc. which executive power separated from legislative power) > autocracy, aristocracy,  or democracy…. republican or despotic
KA.EP.linkedContent: democracy refers to who can hold the highest power > republic refers to method by which people are governed (republicanism: principle acc. which executive power separated from legislative power) > autocracy, aristocracy, or democracy…. republican or despotic

KA.EP.content: yield to moral principle of good, though in slow profession
